Award.AwardTitle: East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Anna Herring of Oregon State University to conduct a research project, entitled "How the chemistry of rock surfaces affects trapping of carbon dioxide" during the summer of 2012 at Australia National University in Canberra, Australia. The host scientist is Adrian Sheppard.

This research extends knowledge of multiphase fluid flow and capillary trapping, specifically in application to geologic sequestration of supercritical carbon dioxide. It examines and quantifies the effect of modifying wettability on capillary trapping of various fluids within Bentheimer sandstone cores. The results will guide efforts to engineer carbon dioxide injection scenarios to optimize trapping, which is crucial for the success of geologic sequestration projects. In addition, better understanding of the physics involved in multi-phase flow in porous media is not only necessary for optimization of geologic carbon dioxide sequestration but can be applied to many other fields of research, e.g. groundwater hydraulics, remediation of non-aqueous phase liquids (NAPLs) in the subsurface, and oil recovery operations.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on understanding how different fluids flow through porous sandstone under different surface chemistry conditions. Bentheimer sandstone cores were treated to modify their wettability state (i.e. the degree of hydrophillicity or hydrophobicity exhibited by the solid surface). Brine and air were pumped through the rock cores, and then the total fluid amount and pore scale distribution of the fluids was quantified using x-ray microtomography (x-ray CMT). Tomography is a non-destructive method of sample analysis which utilizes collecting a series of x-ray radiographs to construct a 3D image of the interior of a sample; microtomography is the application of this technology to resolve features on the micron scale.

The goal of this research was to try to determine how wettability conditions will affect how CO2 is transported and trapped underground during a geologic CO2 sequestration scheme. Currently, there is debate as to which fluid and media properties are the most important in trapping of CO2, and this debate extends to the larger field of multi-phase flow in porous media. Better understanding of the physics involved in these processes is not only necessary for optimization of geologic CO2 sequestration, but also many other fields of research as well- e.g. groundwater hydraulics, remediation of non-aqueous phase liquids (NAPLs) in the subsurface, and oil recovery operations.

Future presentation and publication of the data obtained in this study has the potential to generate interest and cooperation from researchers in multiple fields due to the unique application of 3-D imaging: the ability to visualize flow processes within solid media makes the study more accessible to students and researchers from a wider array of disciplines, which promotes collaboration between different fields. Public presentation of the data gained from this study will provide more exposure for x-ray CMT as a method of sample analysis, which could have many benefits in a wide variety of areas of study.

The travel component of this project was very successful in terms of establishing and strengthening connections between researchers at Oregon State University and Australian National University. The availability of high-end x-ray CMT systems is somewhat limited across the globe, and cooperation between researchers with access to these instruments is crucial to obtaining good data and realizing accurate intepretations. For the EAPSI fellow, the opportunity to work in a laboratory with experts in surface chemistry  and rock characterization was invaluable; and the experience of working with the state-of-the-art CMT facility at ANU was extremely worthwhile and instructive. In reciprocation, the fellow was able to assist others in the laboratory with her knowledge and experience of conducting flow experiments.  It is anticipated that future collaboration between the groups at OSU and ANU will be much enhanced due to the EAPSI program.

The EAPSI program for this fellow resulted in a better understanding of CO2 movement and trapping for sequestration applications as well as a more thorough understanding of multi-phase flow in general. It has and will continue to provide the opportunity and the means to interest and engage more researchers in this topic as well as the use of x-ray tomography as an analytical technique. Finally, the EAPSI program has certainly lead to the development of a stronger collaborative relationship between Australian and American researchers.
